title: CVPR_1999_15_abs

sentences.text: In this paper we specialize the projective unifocal , bifo-cal , and trifocal tensors to the affine case , and show how the tensors obtained relate to the registered tensors encountered in previous work .
This enables us to obtain an affine specialization of known projective relations connecting points and lines across two or three views .
In the simpler case of affine cameras we give neccessary and sufficient constraints on the components of the trifocal tensor , together with a simple geometric interpretation .
Finally , we show how the estimation of the tensors from point correspondences is achieved through factorization , and discuss the estimation from line correspondences .

Entity-projective_unifocal__bifo-cal__an.label: projective unifocal, bifo-cal, and trifocal tensors
aliases: the projective unifocal, bifo-cal, and trifocal tensors
projective unifocal, bifo-cal, and trifocal tensors
Entity-projective_unifocal__bifo-cal__an.description: Projective unifocal, bifo-cal, and trifocal tensors are mathematical constructs used in computer vision to describe the geometric relationships between points and lines across multiple views, particularly when specialized to the affine case.

mentions.local_name: projective unifocal, bifo-cal, and trifocal tensors
the projective unifocal, bifo-cal, and trifocal tensors

Entity-the_tensor_obtained.label: the tensors obtained
Entity-the_tensor_obtained.description: The tensors obtained refer to the specialized affine versions of projective unifocal, bifocal, and trifocal tensors that are derived in the paper, which relate to previously established registered tensors and facilitate the understanding of geometric relationships in multi-view scenarios.

Entity-bifo-cal.label: bifo-cal
Entity-bifo-cal.description: bifo-cal refers to a type of tensor that is specialized in the context of affine geometry, specifically relating to the projective unifocal and trifocal tensors, and is used to establish connections between points and lines across multiple views.

Entity-affine_specialization.label: affine specialization
Entity-affine_specialization.description: Affine specialization refers to the adaptation of projective relations in geometry to the affine case, specifically in the context of connecting points and lines across multiple views using affine tensors.

Entity-projective_unifocal.label: projective unifocal
Entity-projective_unifocal.description: The projective unifocal refers to a specific type of tensor that is specialized in the context of affine geometry, used to establish projective relations between points and lines across multiple views in computer vision.

Entity-affine_case.label: affine case
Entity-affine_case.description: The 'affine case' refers to a specific scenario in the study of projective geometry where projective tensors are specialized to accommodate the properties and constraints of affine transformations, particularly in the context of relating points and lines across multiple views in computer vision.

Entity-registered_tensor.label: registered tensors
Entity-registered_tensor.description: Registered tensors refer to a specific class of tensors that have been previously defined in the literature, which are utilized in the context of projective geometry and are related to the affine specialization of tensor relations connecting points and lines across multiple views.

Entity-line_correspondence.label: line correspondences
Entity-line_correspondence.description: Line correspondences refer to the geometric relationships between lines in different views that are used to estimate tensors in the context of affine camera models.

Entity-simple_geometric_interpretation.label: simple geometric interpretation
Entity-simple_geometric_interpretation.description: The term 'simple geometric interpretation' refers to an intuitive understanding of the necessary and sufficient constraints on the components of the trifocal tensor in the context of affine cameras.

Entity-the_registered_tensor_encountered.label: the registered tensors encountered in previous work
aliases: the registered tensors encountered in previous work
Entity-the_registered_tensor_encountered.description: The registered tensors encountered in previous work refer to specific tensor structures that have been previously defined and utilized in the context of projective geometry and multi-view geometry, which the authors relate to their newly specialized affine tensors.

mentions.local_name: the registered tensors encountered in previous work

Entity-two_or_three_view.label: two or three views
Entity-two_or_three_view.description: The term 'two or three views' refers to the geometric relationships and projective relations that connect points and lines observed from two or three different camera perspectives in the context of affine camera models.

Entity-trifocal_tensor.label: trifocal tensor
Entity-trifocal_tensor.description: The trifocal tensor is a mathematical object that encodes the geometric relationships between three views of a scene in computer vision and is used to facilitate tasks such as 3D reconstruction and motion estimation.

Entity-component_of_the_trifocal_tensor.label: components of the trifocal tensor
Entity-component_of_the_trifocal_tensor.description: The components of the trifocal tensor are mathematical elements that represent the geometric relationships between three views of a scene in computer vision and multi-view geometry.

Entity-known_projective_relation.label: known projective relations
Entity-known_projective_relation.description: Known projective relations refer to established mathematical relationships that connect points and lines across multiple views in projective geometry, which are specialized in this paper to the affine case.

Entity-estimation_of_the_tensor_from_poi.label: estimation of the tensors from point correspondences
aliases: estimation of the tensors from point correspondences
the estimation of the tensors from point correspondences
Entity-estimation_of_the_tensor_from_poi.description: The estimation of the tensors from point correspondences refers to the mathematical process of determining tensor values based on the relationships and correspondences between points in a given dataset.

mentions.local_name: estimation of the tensors from point correspondences
the estimation of the tensors from point correspondences

Entity-point.label: points
Entity-point.description: In the context of the paper, 'points' refers to geometric entities that are used to establish projective relations between lines and views in affine camera systems.

Entity-view.label: views
Entity-view.description: The term 'views' refers to the distinct perspectives or visual representations captured by cameras in the context of projective relations connecting points and lines in affine geometry.

Entity-affine_camera.label: affine cameras
Entity-affine_camera.description: Affine cameras are a type of optical system that model the geometric relationships between points in three-dimensional space and their projections onto a two-dimensional image plane, characterized by linear transformations without perspective effects.

Entity-point_and_line.label: points and lines
Entity-point_and_line.description: In the context of projective geometry, 'points and lines' refer to fundamental geometric entities that represent the locations and linear relationships in a multi-view framework, particularly in the study of affine transformations and tensor relations.

Entity-line.label: lines
Entity-line.description: In the context of the paper, 'lines' refers to geometric entities that represent the relationships between points in projective geometry, specifically in the study of affine transformations and their connections across multiple views.

Entity-projective_relation.label: projective relations
Entity-projective_relation.description: Projective relations refer to the mathematical connections that describe the geometric relationships between points and lines in projective space, particularly in the context of multiple views in computer vision.

Entity-point_correspondence.label: point correspondences
Entity-point_correspondence.description: Point correspondences refer to pairs of points that are identified as corresponding to each other in different geometric configurations or images, often used in the context of geometric transformations and computer vision.

Entity-tensor.label: tensors
Entity-tensor.description: Tensors are mathematical objects that generalize scalars, vectors, and matrices to higher dimensions, often used in various fields such as physics, engineering, and computer science to represent multi-dimensional data.

Entity-estimation_from_line_corresponden.label: estimation from line correspondences
Entity-estimation_from_line_corresponden.description: Estimation from line correspondences refers to a method of deriving geometric or spatial information by analyzing the relationships and correspondences between lines in a given dataset or image.

Entity-factorization.label: factorization
Entity-factorization.description: Factorization is a mathematical and computational process used to decompose a complex object, such as a matrix or tensor, into simpler components or factors, often to facilitate analysis or estimation.

Entity-geometric_interpretation.label: geometric interpretation
Entity-geometric_interpretation.description: Geometric interpretation refers to the representation or understanding of mathematical concepts and relationships through geometric figures and visualizations.

Entity-previous_work.label: previous work
Entity-previous_work.description: previous work refers to earlier research or academic contributions that have been conducted in a related field or topic.

Entity-neccessary_and_sufficient_constra.label: neccessary and sufficient constraints
Entity-neccessary_and_sufficient_constra.description: Necessary and sufficient constraints are conditions that must be met for a particular solution or outcome to be valid, ensuring that the solution is both required and adequate for the problem at hand.

summary: In this paper we specialize the projective unifocal , bifo-cal , and trifocal tensors to the affine case , and show how the tensors obtained relate to the registered tensors encountered in previous work . This enables us to obtain an affine specialization of known projective relations connecting points and lines across two or three views . In the simpler case of affine cameras we give neccessary and sufficient constraints on the components of the trifocal tensor , together with a simple geometric interpretation . Finally , we show how the estimation of the tensors from point correspondences is achieved through factorization , and discuss the estimation from line correspondences .

Predicate-relate_to.label: relate to
Predicate-relate_to.description: The predicate 'relate to' establishes a connection or association between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject has a relevant or significant link to the object. This connection can imply various forms of relationships, such as similarity, relevance, influence, or dependency, suggesting that understanding one may provide insights into the other.

Predicate-specialize_to.label: specialize to
Predicate-specialize_to.description: The predicate 'specialize to' indicates a relationship where the subject represents a broader or more general category or concept that can be refined or restricted to a more specific instance or case represented by the object. This implies that the subject encompasses the object within its framework, allowing for the application of the principles or characteristics of the subject to the specific context of the object.

Predicate-obtains.label: obtains
Predicate-obtains.description: The predicate 'obtains' indicates a relationship where the subject acquires, achieves, or derives the object, suggesting a process of gaining or securing something that is typically recognized or established. This connection implies that the subject is actively involved in the process of obtaining the object, which is often a result, outcome, or set of information that is valuable or significant in a particular context.

Predicate-connecting.label: connecting
Predicate-connecting.description: The predicate 'connecting' signifies a relationship or action that establishes a link or association between the subject and the object. In this context, it implies that the subject provides a framework or basis that facilitates the interaction, relationship, or correspondence between the elements represented by the object. This connection can manifest in various forms, such as spatial, conceptual, or functional relationships, thereby allowing for a cohesive understanding of how the subject and object relate to one another.

Predicate-across.label: across
Predicate-across.description: The predicate 'across' indicates a relationship of connection or interaction between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject spans, extends, or is relevant to the object in a way that encompasses or involves multiple aspects or perspectives.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' indicates a relationship of possession or existence between the subject and the object, where the subject possesses, contains, or is characterized by the qualities, attributes, or elements represented by the object. In this context, it signifies that the subject is associated with or includes the object as an essential component or requirement.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a relationship of possession or inclusion between the subject and the object, where the subject possesses or contains the object as a part or characteristic. This relationship signifies that the object is an essential or integral component of the subject, contributing to its identity or functionality.

Predicate-apply_to.label: apply to
Predicate-apply_to.description: The predicate 'apply to' indicates a relationship where the subject is relevant or pertinent to the object, suggesting that the subject's principles, rules, or conditions are relevantly directed towards or can be utilized in relation to the object. It implies a functional or contextual connection where the subject influences, governs, or is relevant for understanding or working with the object.

Predicate-is_achieved_through.label: is achieved through
Predicate-is_achieved_through.description: The predicate 'is achieved through' indicates a means or method by which the subject accomplishes or realizes a particular outcome or result represented by the object. It establishes a causal or functional relationship, suggesting that the object serves as a necessary process, technique, or tool that enables the subject to reach its intended goal.

Predicate-is_discussed.label: is discussed
Predicate-is_discussed.description: The predicate 'is discussed' indicates that the subject is the topic of conversation or analysis, and the object represents the specific aspect or instance of that topic being examined or elaborated upon. This relationship suggests an exchange of ideas or information regarding the subject, often involving various perspectives or insights.

Predicate-are_specialized_to.label: are specialized to
Predicate-are_specialized_to.description: The predicate 'are specialized to' indicates a relationship where the subject refers to a specific category or type of entities that have been adapted or refined to produce or relate to the object, which represents the resulting entities or outcomes. This suggests that the subject has undergone a process of specialization that enables it to effectively function or be relevant in the context of the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or subset that falls under the more general category represented by the object. This relationship implies that the object encompasses a wider range of entities or concepts, of which the subject is a part.
